data.title: I need to vent. I want to enjoy Elden Ring, but I can't anymore. The game doesn't stop crashing every 5 minutes, over and over again.

data.text:
One more update, now version 1.08, one more time that the problem isn't fix. It took a grand total of 15 minutes for the game to crash again. And then 5 more to crash a second time.

First I was plagued with invisible enemies. But your CPU is old people said, and they were right. Even though people with excellent PCs also had this problem and a 300kb mod solved the issue. But it was past time I updated my PC, so I did. Now I'm over specs.

And it did solve that issue! But now there are the crashes. It wasn't like that in the beginning, there were crashes but there were not enough to bother me. But since I reinstalled the game a few months back? Crash after crash after crash. I tried every solution that I could find, I updated my GPU several times during this time, checked the integrity of the games files three times that much, reinstalled the game, reinstalled the game in a different hd, updated windows, updated by BIOS, turned off any kind of gaming profile and overlays, and many other small solutions that I found online.

Nothing works.

It's always the same crash, a quick stutter and then a hard freeze. It happens when I'm walking, on a horse, fighting enemies, not fighting enemies, fighting bosses, not fighting bosses, when I'm summoned, when I'm not summoned. I do think it doesn't happen when I'm in caves, but it does happen in legacy dungeons. Malenia fight for example crashed every single time in her second phase. Every. Single. Time. Makes me feel nostalgic for that time all I had to do is dodge Waterfowl Dance.

Thank you for listening to my rant. Maybe the next update will fix it. ðŸ¤¡

The next time it happens check the event viewer and look for anything under Application and System at the time of the crash. Just open up the start menu and type Event Viewer and it should appear.

I had odd issues where a game for some reason was triggering my machines sleep status and wake status immediately, so what I had was my display flicker and then it would come back and the game would have a black screen and need to be force closed and it was caused by ASUS power management for some reason thinking it was seeing a sleep button being triggered during the game. Only 1 game and to fix it I had to disable the sleep being enabled by button press. Dumb but it worked but event viewer gave me an idea what was happening.

Ok have you tried a full GPU driver uninstall? Try uninstalling the GPU drivers, restart the computer then go directly to the manufacturers website and download and install the latest drivers available there. If that doesn't resolve it as others have said event viewer should give you some more information that will help determine what might be the cause. Is the crash only happening in Elden Ring? Have you played other games without any issues? If so, what games have you tried to play?

Ok, I got a word from the event viewer: nvlddmkm

Does it mean anything?

Yeah so, Elden Ring at its current state is a very stable game. If you're suffering from crashes, it's probably your pc.

Now, nvlddmkm.

There are some possibilities. First is your nvidia drivers are corrupted / in conflict with some older files. Search on the web on how to manually erase drivers because the clean option while installing geforce drivers isn't 100% cleaning.

Next, this could mean your gpu isn't stable. Did you overclock your gpu? If yes, put all values by default. If it still crashes, check your gpu core temp. Is it in the 50s? The 60s? The 70s? 80s? A hot gpu tends to be less stable, especially over time. You may need to lower the power limit of your card / raise the gpu fan speed manually.

If it still crashes, swap your gpu to another and try playing with a different one and see how it goes.

I'll echo what others were saying. In my 130 hours the game ran not so good at times. The worst being the double gargoyle boss fight which dropped below 30FPS for no real reason. However I can say it never crashed of all things.

As others have already said DDU and a clean install of the GPU is definitely where I'd start first. nvlddmkm crashes are usually GPU related, be it to do with the driver, or hardware itself. Following that I'd maybe try installing MSI After burner and trying to lower the gpu core clock to see if you can get it stable. GPU's can lose their ability to keep core clocks over time if they've been used a lot, and if the core clock is unstable the game crashing out is usually what happens. You can also try lowering the power limit too, which might also show if its a power draw issue too.
